title: Authenticating with Pluto
text: ’re accessing data programmatically first time, ’ll need generate new API token. Navigate Account page Pluto click “+ API token” button. new API token generated, can copied viewed.  API token can used fetch data programmatically using R package. respect permissions Pluto, can used access Projects Experiments permission view. Make sure protect API token don’t share others. API tokens can deleted time clicking “Delete token” link Account page.

what: Option 1: Provide API token interactively / at run-time
title: Authenticating with Pluto
text: can “log ” Pluto interactively providing API token pluto_login helper function. save API key current environment can used subsequent API calls current session, simply provide API key: can also use save_Renviron = T save API key current environment save .Renviron file referenced future sessions. shortcut achieves outcome manual Option #2 described .
code: library(pluto)  pluto_login("<Your API key>") pluto_login("<Your API key>", save_Renviron = T)

what: Option 2: Use the PLUTO_API_TOKEN environment variable
title: Authenticating with Pluto
text: using Pluto one R projects, convenient save API token environment variable can easily referenced running scripts project. Copy API token created Account page store environment variable called PLUTO_API_TOKEN. , create .Renviron file containing: Save file, restart R session apply changes. confirm API token active R environment time, can run Sys.getenv("PLUTO_API_TOKEN").

title: Getting started with data integration

title: Getting started with Pluto
text: See vignette("authentication") instructions creating personal API token accessing data. begin using pluto, load package log personal API token:

title: Getting started with Pluto
text: Pluto data stored several data models, described depth vignette("pluto_models"). purposes quick start guide, ’ll highlight main ones: Project - collection Experiments type - known/predefined assay type Pluto (e.g. rnaseq, cutandrun, proteomics) Sample Data - tabular annotations metadata associated samples Assay Data - tabular measurements assay (e.g. counts matrix gene expression experiments) Results - tabular results generated Analysis, format depends kind analysis run Using models, can read data Pluto R scripts flexible way serve wide variety needs applications. basic examples intended illustrate foundational building blocks working Pluto data models.

what: Fetch data for a single experiment in Pluto
title: Getting started with Pluto
text: example, ’ll use public ChIP-seq experiment GEO (GSE150555) imported Pluto: Effect WDR5 degrader H3K4me2 human cancer cell lines. Pluto ID experiment (found url) PLX191681.

previous_headings: Interacting with Pluto data models > Fetch data for a single experiment in Pluto
title: Getting started with Pluto
text: Pluto, sample annotations stored tabular format automatic enriching metadata fields like cell lines.  read sample annotations R script, provide experiment ID pluto_read_sample_data() function:

what: Introduction to the Pluto data models
title: Pluto data models
text: Pluto data stored several data models: Project - collection Experiments type - known/predefined assay type Pluto (e.g. rnaseq, cutandrun, proteomics) Sample Data - tabular annotations metadata associated samples Assay Data - tabular measurements assay (e.g. counts matrix gene expression experiments) Results - tabular results generated Analysis, format depends kind analysis run

title: Getting started with scRNA-seq
text: See vignette("authentication") instructions creating personal API token accessing data. begin using pluto, load package log personal API token:

title: Getting started with scRNA-seq
text: Single cell RNA-seq Pluto creates two Seurat objects: raw Seurat object, created beginning single cell RNA-seq preprocessing workflow filtered, normalized, integrated, clustered, etc.; final Seurat object, final, processed Seurat object results completing accepting preprocess workflow. Seurat objects accessible external scRNA-seq analysis via pluto package.

title: Getting started with scRNA-seq
text: download Seurat object, provide experiment ID, Seurat type ("raw" "final") pluto_download_seurat_object() function (can also provide optional desired destination file path setting dest_filename):

title: Getting started with scRNA-seq
text: read Seurat object directly R script, provide experiment ID Seurat type ("raw" "final") pluto_read_seurat_object() function: important note pluto_read_seurat_object() function returns different objects depending Seurat type specified. Seurat type specified "raw", Seurat object returned. Seurat type specified "final", list returned containing final Seurat object, obj, custom cluster annotations added Seurat meta.data custom color palettes corresponding cluster annotation sets -app, colors.
code: experiment_id <- "PLX037839" seurat_type <- "raw" so <- pluto_read_seurat_object(experiment_id, seurat_type) experiment_id <- "PLX037839" seurat_type <- "final" final_obj <- pluto_read_seurat_object(experiment_id, seurat_type)  # To access the Seurat object so <- final_obj$obj  # To access the custom color palettes custom_palettes <- final_obj$colors

title: Getting started with scRNA-seq
text: Seurat object, developed Satija lab, representation single-cell expression data R. object serves container contains data (like count matrix) analysis (like PCA, clustering results) single cell dataset. top level, Seurat object serves collection Assay DimReduc objects, representing expression data dimensionality reductions expression data, respectively. Seurat objects also store additional metadata, cell feature level. Click information. access Seurat object assay(s): access Seurat object reductions: access Seurat object meta.data: column names meta.data correspond variables latent variables see Pluto app. also see additional columns added preprocess workflow, mostly related QC. reading final Seurat object, see columns correspond cluster annotation sets. get list available meta.data columns Seurat object:
code: so@assays so@reductions so@meta.data  # Or, to just display the first n rows of meta.data: head(so@meta.data, n = 10) colnames(so@meta.data)

title: Getting started with scRNA-seq
text: Seurat object downloaded Pluto, can use variety base plotting functions Seurat package. can modify customize plots using ggplot2.

title: Getting started with scRNA-seq
text: Using Seurat DimPlot() function, make scatter plot UMAP space grouping cells custom annotation set “Default cluster - res. 1.0” (, can use one custom color palettes defined Pluto app):  Using Seurat DimPlot() function, make scatter plot UMAP space grouping cells timepoint:  Using Seurat DimPlot() function, make scatter plot UMAP space grouping cells custom annotation set “Default cluster - res. 1.0” splitting cells timepoint:
code: DimPlot(so, # the Seurat object         reduction = "umap", # could also be "tsne" or "pca"         group.by = "default_clusters_res_0_1", # custom annotation set         cols = custom_palettes$default_clusters_res_0_1, # custom color palette         pt.size = 0.1) + # point size for plotting   labs(title = "Default clusters - res. 0.1", # update plot title        x = "UMAP 1", # update x-axis label        y = "UMAP 2") # update y-axis label # Create a custom color palette to group cells by timepoint timepoint_cols <- c("#14b8a6", "#fcd34d", "#ef4444") names(timepoint_cols) <- c("24hpf", "36hpf", "48hpf")  DimPlot(so, # the Seurat object         reduction = "umap", # could also be "tsne" or "pca"         group.by = "timepoint", # available column in our meta.data, from our Pluto sample data         cols = timepoint_cols,         pt.size = 0.1) + # point size for plotting   labs(title = "Timepoint", # update plot title        x = "UMAP 1", # update x-axis label        y = "UMAP 2") # update y-axis label DimPlot(so, # the Seurat object         reduction = "umap", # could also be "tsne" or "pca"         group.by = "default_clusters_res_0_1", # custom annotation set         cols = custom_palettes$default_clusters_res_0_1, # custom color palette         split.by = "timepoint", # custom annotation set         pt.size = 0.1) + # point size for plotting   labs(title = "Default clusters - res. 0.1", # update plot title        x = "UMAP 1", # update x-axis label        y = "UMAP 2") # update y-axis label

previous_headings: Visualization using the Seurat package > Marker feature expression
title: Getting started with scRNA-seq
text: Using Seurat VlnPlot() function, make violin plot grouping cells custom annotation set “Default cluster - res. 1.0”:
code: VlnPlot(so, # the Seurat object         features = c("olig2"), # feature(s) of interest         group.by = "default_clusters_res_0_1", # custom annotation set         cols = custom_palettes$default_clusters_res_0_1) + # custom color palette   labs(title = "Expression of olig2", # update plot title        x = "Default clusters - res. 0.1") # update x-axis label

previous_headings: Visualization using the Seurat package > Marker feature expression
title: Getting started with scRNA-seq
text: Using Seurat RidgePlot() function, make ridge plot grouping cells custom annotation set “Default cluster - res. 1.0”:
code: RidgePlot(so, # the Seurat object           features = c("olig2"), # feature(s) of interest           group.by = "default_clusters_res_0_1", # custom annotation set           cols = custom_palettes$default_clusters_res_0_1) + # custom color palette   labs(title = "Expression of olig2", # update plot title        y = "Default clusters - res. 0.1") + # update x-axis label   theme_ridges(center = TRUE) # center the x and y axis labels

previous_headings: Visualization using the Seurat package > Marker feature expression
title: Getting started with scRNA-seq
text: Using Seurat FeaturePlot() function, make scatter plot UMAP space colored feature expression:
code: FeaturePlot(so, # the Seurat object             features = c("olig2"), # feature(s) of interest             reduction = "umap", # could also be "tsne" or "pca"             pt.size = 0.1) + # point size for plotting   labs(title = "Expression of olig2", # update plot title        x = "UMAP 1", # update x-axis label        y = "UMAP 2") # update y-axis label

previous_headings: Visualization using the Seurat package > Marker feature expression
title: Getting started with scRNA-seq
text: Using Seurat DotPlot() function, make dot plot colored feature expression:  visualization tutorials using Seurat package, check Seurat visualization vignette .
code: DotPlot(so, # the Seurat object         features = c("olig2", "sox19a", "gfap", "dlb", "nkx2.2a"), # feature(s) of interest         group.by = "default_clusters_res_0_1") + # custom annotation set   labs(title = "Key marker genes", # update plot title        x = "Genes", # update x-axis label        y = "Default clusters - res. 0.1") # update y-axis label

title: Query and manipulate biological data stored in Pluto
text: pluto official R package interacting Pluto, biological discovery platform. lines code, can read data results directly R scripts, push custom plots back Pluto remain interactive collaborative. using Pluto yet? ’d happy show platform action - schedule personalized demo.

title: Query and manipulate biological data stored in Pluto
text: Install latest version Github: installed, can load Pluto R package scripts library(pluto).
code: # Install devtools if you don't already have it install.packages("devtools")  # Install the pluto R package remotes::install_github("pluto-biosciences/pluto-sdk-r")

title: Query and manipulate biological data stored in Pluto
text: typical, minimal workflow using pluto involves: Authenticate Pluto API token (see vignette("authentication")) Fetch data one experiments Perform custom analysis (see vignette("rnaseq_recipes") inspiration ✨) Push results back Pluto canvas also numerous ways use pluto larger scale, example multiple data sets integrating -house tools. examples include: Fetching RNA-seq experiments project performing meta-analysis differential expression results Fetching four different NGS experiments (e.g. RNA-seq, ChIP-seq, CUT&RUN, ATAC-seq) overlapping differential regions identify regions expression binding altered

what: Working with an outsourced bioinformatics team?
title: Query and manipulate biological data stored in Pluto
text: Pluto, cross-functional team power collaborate easily one place regardless coding ability. applies vendors well! Instead outsourced bioinformatics vendor send results email folders critical findings easily lost, can request deliver data results directly back Pluto lab space. training necessary part - Pluto handles onboarding training bioinformatics CROs collaborating clients Pluto part service. can sit back watch results come . Chat Customer Experience team learn .

title: Query and manipulate biological data stored in Pluto
text: ’re help! Feel free reach support@pluto.bio email Pluto customer representative directly.

title: Query and manipulate biological data stored in Pluto
text: running tests developing pluto R package, need decrypt encrypted .Renviron file repo. Decrypt encrypted .Renviron file need decrypt .Renviron file first time start working repo, time developers made changes. ’s good practice check regularly updates. make modifications .Renviron file (e.g. adding new experiments testing, variables), encrypt file check Encrypt modified .Renviron file Check updated .Renviron.encrypted opening PR developers latest changes.

title: Query and manipulate biological data stored in Pluto
text: testing making changes, ’ll frequently want run devtools::load_all() load recent changes functions. run tests: devtools::test() Note tests test suite integration tests, require specific API token uuids present .Renviron file. run single test: devtools::test_active_file("tests/testthat/<R script name>") example devtools::test_active_file("tests/testthat/test-projects.R")

title: Query and manipulate biological data stored in Pluto
text: build pkgdown site: pkgdown::build_site() update man pages / documentation editing functions: devtools::document()

title: pluto 0.1.0
text: Simplified API request syntax increased performance improved maintainability Added new functions pluto_create_external_plot() pluto_update_external_plot() support simplified endpoints creating updating external plots Updated pluto_add_experiment_plot() pluto_update_external_plot() use new simplified endpoints support script file uploads, maintaining backward compatibility old parameter names (analysis_name plot_methods)

title: pluto 0.0.1
text: Added family pluto_get_*() functions retrieve data Pluto API Added family pluto_read_*() functions read Pluto data directly data.frame Added function pluto_add_experiment_plot() upload HTML image files Experiment Pluto
